title: law
comment: The God-given regulation of the life of the people of God in relationship with him. As the command of God, it enables and gives shape to the relationship between God and human beings on the one hand, and between fellow human beings on the other.

children.title: law, purpose of
children.comment: The law covers and regulates every area of life of the covenant people of God in accordance with the commands of God. Although the laws may be divided into categories of civil, criminal, social and cultic (or ritual) law, these distinctions are not clear-cut, and occasionally overlap with one another.

law, Ten Commandments
children.comment: The basic laws given to Israel through Moses following the exodus from Egypt (Ex 20:1-17; Dt 5:6-21). The first four commandments safeguard Israel's special relation to God; the remaining six protect individuals within the community and promote their well-being.

law, OT
children.comment: OT laws and legal traditions govern every aspect of the life of the covenant people of God.

children.title: Kinds of OT law

primaryrefs.comment: Criminal law deals with crimes against persons punishable by a court.

children.title: Civil law

primaryrefs.comment: Civil law deals with the upholding in court of legally established rights against possible abuse.

children.title: Social law

primaryrefs.comment: Social law deals with behaviour or standards of behaviour which are not strictly enforceable in the courts.

law, and gospel
children.comment: The law, which bears witness to the grace of God, points ahead to its fulfilment and climax in the gospel of Jesus Christ. The gospel does not abolish the law, but fulfils it, by allowing it to be seen in its proper light.

law, letter and spirit of
children.comment: A rigid adherence to the letter of the law often masks hypocrisy and neglect of its spirit, namely having God at the centre of one's life and putting others before oneself, or recognising that the law points to Jesus Christ.
